question: Deputy minister, what do you believe is behind this recent increase in terrorist bombings?
answer: Bad sportsmanship. A ruthless minority of people seems to have forgotten certain good old fashioned virtues. They just can't stand seeing the other fellow win. If these people would just play the game, instead of standing on the touch line heckling -

question: In fact, killing people -
answer: - In fact, killing people - they'd get a lot more out of life.

question: Mr. HELPMANN, what would you say to those critics who maintain that the Ministry Of Information has become too large and unwieldy ...?
answer: David ... in a free society information is the name of the game. You can't win the game if you're a man short.

question: And the cost of it all, Deputy Minister? Seven percent of the gross national produce ...
answer: I understand this concern on behalf of the tax-payers. People want value for money and a cost-effective service. That is why we always insist on the principle of Information Retrieval Charges. These terrorists are not pulling their weight, and it's absolutely right and fair that those found guilty should pay for their periods of detention and the Information Retrieval Procedures used in their interrogation.

question: Do you think that the government is winning the battle against terrorists?
answer: On yes. Our morale is much higher than theirs, we're fielding all their strokes, running a lot of them out, and pretty consistently knocking them for six. I'd say they're nearly out of the game.

question: But the bombing campaign is now in its thirteenth year ...
answer: Beginner's luck.

question: Thank you very much, Deputy Minister.
answer: Thank you, David ... and a very merry Christmas to you all.

question: I hereby inform you under powers entrusted to me under Section 47, Paragraph 7 of Council Order Number 438476, that Mr Buttle, Archibald, residing at 412 North Tower, Shangri La Towers, has been invited to assist the Ministry of Information with certain enquiries, the nature of which may be ascertained on completion of application form BZ/ST/486/C fourteen days within this date, and that he is liable to certain obligations as specified in Council Order 173497, including financial restitutions which may or may not be incurred if Information Retrieval procedures beyond those incorporated in Article 7 subsections 8, 10 & 32 are required to elicit information leading to permanent arrest - notification of which will he served with the time period of 5 working days as stipulated by law. In that instance the detainee will be debited without further notice through central banking procedures without prejudice until and unless at such a time when re-imbursement procedures may be instituted by you or third parties on completion of a re-imbursement form RB/CZ/907/X ... Sign here please.
answer: What? where have you taken him?

question: thank you. Same again please. Just there. Press harder his time. Good.
answer: What is this all about?

question: Hello ... What ... what? Oh ... Mr Kurtzman! ... You're up late. Oh, is it? The electronics here are up the spout. Yours too, sir? Don't worry sir - I'll be there.
answer: Sam!

question: Jack!
answer: Long time no see!

question: Well, since you disappeared up the ladder of Information Retrieval ... I don't expect to see you slumming in Records - what's the problem?
answer: Problem? - No problem - yes, everything's going fantastically well, wonderful, marvelous, great career prospects, Alison in great shape, kids fine, beautiful home, I'm on Security Level Five now, and Mr Helpmann relies on me more and more, yes, couldn't be better, I feel terrifically motivated and job- rewarded -

question: You sound worried.
answer: Me? - if I'm worried about anyone, it's you. What happened to you, Sam? You were the brightest of us - What's the matter?

question: Sorry. Nothing. See you - I'm going to be late.
answer: You are late.

question: Even later.
answer: Sam, your life is going wrong - let your friends tell you - Records is a dead end department, no Security Level worth a damn, it's impossible to get noticed -

question: Yes, I know, fantastic, marvellous, wonderful - remember me to Alison - and the - er - twins.
answer: Triplets.

question: I want to report a wrongful arrest.
answer: You want Information Adjustments. Different department.

question: I've been to Information Adjustments. They sent me here. They told me you had a form I had to fill in.
answer: Have you got an Arrest Receipt?

question: Yes.
answer: Is it stamped?

question: Stamped?
answer: No, there's no stamp on it. You see! I can't give you the form until it's stamped.

question: Where do I get it stamped?
answer: Information Adjustments.

question: Perhaps the machine's on the blink! It keeps picking up old films. That can't he right, can it?
answer: It's not the machine. There's a mismatch on the personnel code numbers... Ah there we go! That's a B58/732 when it should be a T47/215 ... Tuttle ... he should have 31.06, debited against his account for electrical procedures, not Buttle.

question: Oh my God, a mistake!
answer: It's not our mistake!

question: Isn't it? Whose is it?
answer: Information Retrieval.

question: Oh, good!
answer: Expediting has put in for electrical procedures in respect of Buttle, Archibald, shoe repair operative, but Security has invoiced Admin for Tuttle, Archibald, heating engineer

question: What a relief! I don't know what I'd do if you ever got promoted.
answer: Don't worry.

question: But if they did promote you
answer: I've told you before. I'd turn it down.

question: Would you really, Sam?
answer: Really.

question: You've been promoted. It's your mother isn't it? Pulling strings again.
answer: What a BITCH!

question: My God, it works.
answer: Mr Helpmann was very close to your poor father. He was very close to me. Still is. He'll take you under his wing at Information Retrieval. You'll like it when you get there.

question: You're not listening, mother.
answer: It's a present for my son. I hope you like it. It's very exclusive.

question: What is it?
answer: It's something for executives. Hello, Spiro. Merry Christmas.

question: It's something for executives. Hello, Spiro. Merry Christmas.
answer: I'm sorry but ...

question: You remember Samuel, my son.
answer: {suddenly unctious) Oh, but of course ...

question: A most perceptive choice, Madam, if I may say so. Monsieur?
answer: A steak, please. Rare. Mother, I need to ...

question: Monsieur. Quel numero.
answer: I don't know which numero.

question: Look - I've got to get back -
answer: Sam ... you haven't had dessert.

question: I'm sorry. I don' t want dessert. I don't want promotion. I don't want anything.
answer: Don't be childish, Samuel. Of course you want something. You must have hopes, wishes, dreams.

question: NO, NOTHING. NOT EVEN DREAMS! I'm taking you to a safe place. A place where they will never be able to get at us ... ever. There's no way they can approach us without being seen. You're safe here. Hello - Central Services - I'm at 579B Block l9, Northwestern Section D - that's exit 1 on Green Pastures Highway at the Orange Blossom Flyover - and I've got trouble with the air- conditioning
answer: Thank you or calling Central Services. am sorry, due to temporary staff shortage, Central Services cannot take service calls centrally between 2300 and 0900 hours - have a nice day - this has not been a recording, incident-

question: This is an emergency!
answer: Thank you for calling Central Services. I am sorry, due -

question: Yes, but. I've got to have a heating engineer
answer: Thank you for calling Cen -

question: Ah ha ... there you are, Sam.
answer: What? How do you know my name?

question: We know everything here. This is the Storeroom of Knowledge.
answer: Then perhaps you can help me. I've lost someone who ...

question: We know that too. You've come to the right place. Oh, yes. We've got everything here. Every bit of knowledge, wisdom, learning ... every experience, every thought neatly filed away.
answer: What? You mean you've got ...

question: Well not exactly. But, if you help us we'll help you. The Forces Of Darkness have won the day ... but, tomorrow is another one
answer: What do I have to do.

question: You must save the day. This is the Sword Of Truth ... and this the Helmet Of Justice. And this. completes the outfit. It won't be pleasant but, trust me.
answer: Hello ... hello ...

question: Hello ... hello ...
answer: Hello. Mr Lowry?

question: Who's that?
answer: Put the phone down and your hands up.

question: What? Who is this?
answer: Nice and easy now. Keep your hands where I can see them.

question: What is this? Who the hell are you?
answer: Harry Tuttle. Heating engineer. At your service.

question: Tuttle! Are you from Central Services?
answer: Ha!!

question: But ... I called Central Services.
answer: They're a bit overworked these days. Luckily I intercepted your call.

question: What? Wait a minute, what was that business with the gun?
answer: A little precaution, sir. I've had traps set for me before now. There are people in Central Services who'd love to get their hands on Harry Tuttle.

question: Are you saying this is illegal?
answer: Well, yes ... and no. Officially, only Central Service operatives are supposed to touch this stuff ... Could you hold these. ... but, with all the new rules and regulations ... unncgh, c'mon, c'mon ... they can't get decent staff any more ... so ... they tend to turn a blind eye ... as long as I'm careful. ... Mind you, if ever they could prove I'd been working on their equipment ... well, that's a different matter ... up a bit with the torch, sir.

question: Sorry. wouldn't it be easier just to work for Central Services?
answer: Couldn't stand the pa - ah - we're getting warm -

question: The pace?
answer: The paperwork, couldn't stand the paperwork. Over to the left please, if you don't mind sir. Hold it there. Yes, there's more bits of paper in Central Services than bits of pipe - read this, fill in that, hand in the other - listen, this old system of yours could be on fire and I couldn't even turn on the kitchen tap without filling in a 27B/6.... Bloody paperwork.

question: Well I suppose one has to expect a certain amount
answer: Why? I came into this game for adventure - go anywhere, travel light, get in, get out, wherever there's trouble, a man alone. Now they've got the whole country sectioned of and you can't move without a form. I'm the last of a breed. Ah ha! Found it! There's your problem.

question: Can you fix it?
answer: No. But I can bypass it with one of these

question: Fine.
answer: Are you expecting anyone?

question: Fixed itself.
answer: ...ixed itself.

question: Machines don't fix themselves.
answer: ... fix themselves.

question: He's tampered with it, Dowser.
answer: ...ampered. with it, Spoor.

question: No you can't. Just a minute! Have you got a 27B/6?
answer: Now look what you've done to him.

question: Have you got one or haven't you?
answer: Not ... as such ... But we can get one. It's all right, Terry, it's all right, everything's all right.

question: I'm sorry, but I'm a bit of a stickler for paper work. Where would we be if we didn't follow the correct procedures?
answer: We'll be back.

question: Thank you.
answer: Thanks, Lowry, you're a good man in a tight corner.

question: Listen .. um ... I don't want to get involved in any of this. But I work at the Ministry of Information, and I happen to know that Information Retrieval have been looking for an Archibald Tuttle, Heating Engineer. You wouldn't by any chance be -
answer: My friends call me Harry. Information Retrieval, eh? Interesting!

question: What do they want you or?
answer: Time to go.

question: Thank you very much. How much will it...?
answer: On the house. You did me a favor. Check the corridor.

question: All clear. Hey that's a dead end. What have we got on today?
answer: Mr Lowry! Would you step in here a moment please. Thank God you're here! We're in terrible trouble! Look at this! Look at this!

question: A cheque.
answer: The refund for Tuttle!

question: Tuttle?
answer: I mean, Buttle! It's been confusion from the word go! He's been wrongly charged for Electromemorytherapy and someone somewhere is trying to make us carry the can!

question: I've never seen a Ministry cheque before.
answer: We've got to get rid of it! There's been a balls-up somewhere, and when the music stops they'll jump on whoever's holding the cheque!

question: Send it to somebody else. Send it to Buttle. It's his cheque.
answer: I've tried that! Population Census have got him down as dormanted, the Central Collective Storehouse computer has got him down as deleted, and the Information Retrieval have got him down as inoperative ... Security has him down as excised., Admin have him down as completed

question: Hang on. He is dead.
answer: Dead! Oh no! That's terrible! We'll never get rid of the damned thing! What are we going to do?

question: Try next of kin.
answer: Next of kin!

question: There we go. Mrs. Veronica Buttle. What's the number on the cheque?
Into memory. Now ... Central Banking ... Buttle, Veronica ... Deposit
answer: Please don't come back! Please don't come back!

question: Problem. She doesn't have a bank account.
answer: Well, that's it! I may as well go and hang myself! This sort of thing couldn't have happened before the stupid seventh tier reorganization! That was Simmons doing! And he and Jeffries always sit together at lunch! The bastards! Ow! Perhaps we can lose it ... behind the filing cabinet ... or destroy it ... burn it ... eat it ...

question: You'd never get away with it. Besides, you can't do that to somebody's refund. It's Christmas. There is one more option.
answer: What?

question: Drive out to Mrs Buttle, give her the cheque, tell her to sign her name on the back, cash it at the corner sweet shop.
answer: That's brilliant!

question: I'll do it for you. Authorise the cheque. What's the address?
answer: Here. What do I do next?

question: Call the motor pool and authorise personal transport.
answer: Of course, of course. Leave it to me. How do I authorize a cheque?

question: Here we are. Pink and blue receipts. All you've got to do is sign these and the back of the cheque.
answer: Oh God! I think I've broken a bone. What a pathetic thing I am.

question: Here. That's it.
answer: You are good to me Sam.

question: Don't mention it. See you later. Excuse me. Can you tell me ... Mrs Buttle Uh, Mrs Buttle? Mrs Buttle ... Are you Mrs Buttle? My name is Lowry - Sam Lowry. I'm from the Ministry of Information. I've come to give you a cheque. It's a refund ... I'm afraid there was a mistake.
answer: Mistake?

question: Yes. Not my department ... I'm only records. It seems that Mr Buttle was overcharged by Information Retrieval. I don't think they usually make mistakes ... but, er ... I suppose we're all human.
answer: My husband's dead, isn't he?

question: Er ... I assure you Mrs Buttle, the Ministry is always very scrupulous about following up and eradicating error. If you have any complaints which you'd like to make, I'd be more than happy to send you the appropriate forms.
answer: What have you done with his body?

question: Um ... Look, I'm very sorry, but I'm afraid I don't know anything about it ... I'm really just delivering the cheque. Er ... If you wouldn't mind signing these receipts I'll go and leave you in peace. Uh ...
answer: He hadn't done anything ... He was good ... What have you done with his body?

question: Wait! Stop! Come back!! Girl ... fair hair ... Wait! It was nothing to do with me! Go away.
answer: Her name is Jill.

question: What? ...Jill? Jill who? Jill who?
answer: Layton.

question: Jill Layton ... You're a very good little girl. What are you doing here?
answer: I'm waiting for my daddy.

question: He will be pleased when he comes home.
answer: Oh ... Sam. I've had the transport pool onto me ... You don't know anything about a personnel transporter gone missing do you?

question: A "personnel" transporter? They've got it wrong. I had a personal transporter. I'll do the paperwork tomorrow -
answer: Is it all right about Mrs Buttle's cheque?

question: I delivered it.
answer: Can I forget it?

question: Yes.
answer: What a relief! I shall probably have nightmares.

question: Damn! Blast!
answer: What's the matter?

question: You don't happen to know how I can get around an IRQ/3 do you?
answer: All information on 3rd Level Suspects is classified.

question: I know that.
answer: All enquiries to Information Retrieval. Which is hopeless, of course. They never tell you anything. But come the time they want something from us ...

question: I've go to accept that promotion to get behind this, haven't I?
answer: Yes. NO! You can't! You've only just turned it down!

question: I never signed the form.
answer: I did it for you.

question: What! Shit!
answer: It's what you wanted isn't it?

question: Yes ... No ... I don't, know.
answer: Come on, before they turn the lights out.

question: It's a 27B/6, what did you think it was? Haven't you got a ballpoint? Now where's he got to? Dowser! What have you got there?
answer: Got there!

question: Mumble ... mumble ... mumble ... Tuttle
answer: Mumble ... Tuttle ...

question: Tuttle! ... mumble! You've had that scab Tuttle here, haven't you?
answer: ...aven't you?

question: Er ... Thanks ...
answer: It's reply paid.

question: Oh ... Thank you very much, mother, but actually -
answer: You don't have to sing it.

question: Oh, right ... Aren't you a bit late? - the party started half an hour ago.
answer: Yes, I know. It's the backlog, everybody complains. Was it all right otherwise?

question: Yes, it was ... very nice ... thank you.
answer: Do you mind if I use your bathroom?

question: Mother? Is that you?
answer: Of course. Isn't it wonderful? The bandages came of this afternoon. Come and join the fun. Everybody's here.

question: Is Mr Helpmann here?
answer: Yes he is - he wants to talk to you.

question: I want to talk to him.
answer: It seems you're the first person ever to turn down a promotion. He thinks you should see a doctor.

question: Actually, I've decided ...
answer: Oh, Louis! You know Sam.

question: Can you believe it?! Just me and my little knife! Snip - snip - slice - slice - Can you believe it?
answer: Congratulations ...

question: And this is just the beginning!!
answer: Really?

question: Sam!
answer: Whatever happened to you?

question: There was a slight complication. Dr. Chapman says it often happens with a delicate skin like mine. Nothing to worry about. He's promised me I'll have these bandages off in a ...
answer: Actually, there's someone I want to meet ...

question: I know, I know ...! Here we are! I'm going to leave you two lovebirds in peace.
answer: I ... uh ... Can I get you a drink, Shirley? Look ... Shirley ... your mother ... and my mother ... they seem to have got the idea ... I mean, I'm terribly flattered, of course, but, um, the thing is, I don't want you to be under any false ...

question: Hello, Jack!
answer: You remember Alison?

question: Hello, Alison. You look different.
answer: And she's been to Dr. Jaffe! {winking at Sam) She doesn't like me telling anyone but she's pleased as anything really.

question: Er, I knew you looked different.
answer: Remember how they used to stick out?

question: What? - Oh, yes - vividly. I used to wonder if they were real. Your ears?
answer: Dr. Jaffe has pinned her ears back.

question: Quite, absolutely - I always thought they were false.
answer: Mr Helpmann!

question: Mr Helpmann!
answer: Hello, Jack.

question: You remember my wife ... Alis -
answer: Of course. Barbara isn't it? How are you?

question: Barbara's very well, thank you, sir. How are you?
answer: Fine, thank you. Hello, Sam. Ida said you might be here. Have you got a minute? Would you excuse us?

question: Of course .... of course ... Come on Alison - Barbara
answer: Thanks very much Sam.

question: Thanks very much Sam.
answer: That's all right Mr Helpmann. Glad to help.

question: If I can help you ...
answer: Well, I ... Sorry ...

question: Your father and I were very close. Of course Jeremiah was senior to me but we were close friends ... especially after the bombing and I keep his name alive at the office every day. It's as though he's there speaking to me - "'ere I am, J.H.!" The ghost in the machine. I know he would have wanted me to help you ... And I promised your mother I'd take you onto the team at information Retrieval. But I gather that ...
answer: Mr Helpmann. I've changed my mind. I'd like to accept the transfer - am I too late?

question: Too late? That's for me to say.
answer: Well ... well, I ...

question: Welcome to Information Retrieval!
answer: My name is Sam Lowry. I have to report to Mr Warren.

question: My name is Sam Lowry. I have to report to Mr Warren.
answer: Thirtieth floor, sir. You're expected.

question: Er, don't you want to search me?
answer: No, sir.

question: My I.D. cards.
answer: No need, sir

question: But I could be anybody.
answer: No you couldn't, sir. This is Information Retrieval. the lift's arrived, sir.

question: Hello.
answer: No, you can't have any more chairs! There's only one left in here now, and I need that to sit on! Oh ... er, sorry. Who are you?

question: Sam Lowry.
answer: Ah, yes, you're the new boy from next door, ha ha! My name's Lime. Harvey Lime. Welcome to Expediting.

question: Ah. Would you mind if I borrowed your computer console?
answer: What?

question: I'll bring it back in ten minutes.
answer: You want to take my console into your office?

question: Yes.
answer: I'll tell you what .... You tell me what and I'll do it for. I'm a bit of a whizz on this thing.

question: Alright. There's someone I want to check out. A woman called Gillian Layton.
answer: A woman eh? I see.

question: I know her age and distinguishing marks. But I need an address or a place of work or something
answer: This is your dream girl, is it?

question: What? Look, let me use the console for a few minutes.
answer: You must be joking - When there's a woman involved - there's no stopping me. Now, let me have that sheet. Sod it, it's broken!

question: You haven't switched it on.
answer: Oh - yes. Look you're putting me off, standing there! Go back to your office and I'll give you a knock when I've finished. Go on. I'm not going to elope with her. Computers are my forte.

question: Gillian Layton, age twenty three, eyes, blue, hair, black, weight, one hundred and twenty-one pounds, distinguishing marks, blemish on right shoulder, scar on left elbow
answer: It's a start isn't it.

question: But I already knew this!
answer: Best to take it slowly where some women are concerned. Hey - that's my desk!

question: What's that? I'm looking for Officer 412/L. Excuse me. Are you officer 412/L? Er, excuse me! Excuse me. Jack!!
answer: SAM! What a surprise!

question: Are you officer 412/L?
answer: Sorry about that ... Mr Helpmann told me you were coming aboard - congratulations!

question: Thanks. Are you officer 412/L?
answer: For my sins. Are you settling in alright?

question: Yes, thanks.
answer: Terrific. I'm really glad you dropped by. Unfortunately, I don't have any time right now I've got a queue of customers to deal with - er, why don't we have a drink tonight?

question: Ah ...
answer: What?

question: I don't want to take up your time now, but I was hoping you could give me some information on somebody. It's a security level three matter and Information Retrieval records says to refer to you.
answer: OK. Come back this afternoon, about four o'clock. If you give me the number of the case, I'll have the dossier here waiting. My tailor,... well worth the investment.

question: I've got numbers all over these - I'm not sure which is the one you want.
answer: Layton! Oh shit!

question: What is it?
answer: You clever bastard! I might have guessed. You only moved in today and you're already hot on the bloody trail.

question: Am I?
answer: Please, Sam, we're going to have to be open to each other on this one. If you make a reputation with this case, it'll be at my expense.

question: How do you mean?
answer: How much do you know?

question: Not much.
answer: Enough though, eh?

question: Not really, no.
answer: OK. OK. Let's not fence around ... This is the situation. Some idiot somewhere in the building, some insect, confused two of our clients, B58/732 and T47/215.

question: B58/732, that's A. Buttle isn't it?
answer: Christ! You do know it all!

question: No, no, I don't. I'm just beginning Honestly. Sorry, carry on.
answer: Well, your A. Buttle has been confused with T47/215, an A. Tuttle. I mean, it's a joke! Somebody should be shot for that. So B58/732 was pulled in by mistake.

question: You got the wrong man.
answer: I did not get the wrong man. I got the right man. The wrong man was delivered to me as the right man! I accepted him, on trust, as the right man. Was I wrong? Anyway, to add to the confusion, he died on us. Which, had he been the right man, he wouldn't have done.

question: You killed him?
answer: Sam, there are very rigid parameters laid down to avoid that event but Buttle's heart condition did not appear on Tuttle's file. Don't think I'm dismissing this business, Sam. I've lost a week's sleep over it already.

question: I'm sure you have
answer: There are some real bastards in this department who don't mind breaking a few eggs to make an omelette, but thank God there are the new boys like me who want to maintain decent civilized standards of terrorist eradication. We've got the upper hand for the moment, but they're waiting for us to slip up, and a little slip- up like this is just the chance they're looking for.

question: So how ...?
answer: What I've got to do now is pick up Tuttle, interrogate him at the same voltage as Buttle, to the same meter reading to the last penny, and juggle the books in electrical banking.

question: What has Tuttle done?
answer: We suspect him of freelance subversion.

question: He's a freelance subversive?
answer: He's a compulsive heating engineer. A maverick ex-Central Service repair man with a grudge against society. Now, fortunately, we're nearly out of the wood, I think. At least we will be when I get this Layton woman under arrest.

question: What's she done?
answer: You didn't know as much about this business as you pretended to, did you?

question: Er ... no.
answer: Very smart.

question: Er ... but I would've found out anyway.
answer: Yes. I'm impressed.

question: Tell me about Layton.
answer: She witnessed the Tuttle arrest - the Buttle arrest - and since then she's been making wild allegations, obviously trying to exploit the situation - she's working for somebody, and she's not working for us.

question: A terrorist? Ah ... thanks. But surely, I mean, perhaps she just happened to live above the Buttles, and ...
answer: Look after that suit, eh. Barbara chose it for me.

question: Right. Er, you're not going to keep calling her Barbara, are you?
answer: Barbara's a perfectly good name, isn't it?

question: Look, about the Layton woman - maybe she's just trying to help the Buttle family.
answer: Why?

question: Why? Hell, not for any reason ...
answer: {baffled) I don't follow you.

question: Out of kindness.
answer: Kindness? What's the purpose behind this line of enquiry?

question: So what are you going to do about her?
answer: Get her out of circulation - I've put her on the detention list.

question: You mean you're going to invite her in so that she can spill the beans inside the department?
answer: Well, I ... Good point. What do you suggest?

question: Let me try to get to her. I'll deactivate her.
answer: What does that mean? I don't want to be involved in anything unsavoury.

question: Trust me. You do trust me, don't you?
answer: Of course. We went to school together. You're my oldest friend.

question: And you're mine.
answer: You're the only person I can trust.

question: Then we'd better keep this business just between the two of us.
answer: Right! Just between as and the Security Forces.

question: They weren't at school with us.
answer: But, I've already put her on the search and detain list.

question: Take her off the list.
answer: There's no procedure for that until she's been arrested.

question: Say it was a mistake.
answer: We don't make mistakes.

question: Well, I'd better get out there and try to get to her before security does. Let me borrow her dossier for a while.
answer: Er ... alright. For Christ's sake don't lose it. Here, you'd better sign for it.

question: Thanks, Jack. I'll be in touch.
answer: Do you know what you're doing.

question: Trust me.
answer: Sam ... we're proud to have you at Information Retrieval. Merry Xmas.

question: What do you think you're doing ... that's the Deputy Minister's lift.
answer: Sorry, I'm in a hurry.

question: Hold on, sonny ... let's see your
answer: Shit ... it's here somewhere. My name's Lowry, Sam Lowry - Expediting ... can't this wait?

question: No, sir ... I'm going to have to file a report on this. Now ... what date is it today?...
answer: Sorry, it'll have to wait.

question: You're a stupid, fat arsed, obstructive, fascist moron aren't you?
answer: If you say so.

question: You think these are tits don't you?
answer: Ah.

question: I bet you'd like to touch them?
answer: Oh.

question: STOP! Let her go! Well done ... uh ... excellent work ... quick thinking. I'll take charge of her now ... Come with me, please.
answer: Who are you? Let go!

question: Don't look back! Act naturally!
answer: How can I act naturally, when you've trying to break my arm?

question: Ow! That hurt!
answer: Good!

question: Oh, God ... no! Well done, that's it ... Let's go! Vrmmm. Vrmmm. What are you doing? For Christ's sake! Get moving!
answer: Who are you?

question: Sam Lowry. Hello. This sounds insane, I know, but I've been dreaming about you. Even before I saw you you were in my dreams. Weird isn't it. I mean ... I don't know what it means ... but it might mean something ... mightn't it? I hope so. Anyway you're in danger and I think we should get out of here, now, quick! Come on! Bloody hell! Do as I say!
answer: No.

question: Please! Alright! Alright! Alright! I'm Information Retrieval Officer - DZ/015, and I'm arresting you for - your own good! Now start up and get moving before I hand you back to them!
answer: Them?

question: Us. Them. I don't know ... just get going.
answer: Don't litter my cab!

question: Oh, sorry. ... This is amazing ... for me ... being here with you. I mean, in my dreams you ...
answer: I don't want to hear about your fucking dreams!

question: Oh. But ... Look, I'm sorry I shouted at you.
answer: Why are they all pigs at Information Retrieval?

question: I don't know. Hey, that's not a very nice thing to say. You know, smoking's bad for you.
answer: It's my fucking life.

question: Yes, of course. Sorry.
answer: I know you. I saw you through the floor, didn't I?

question: Yes. Ceiling. Why did you run away?
answer: I didn't run away. I left the flat.

question: Why?
answer: I didn't like it.

question: Why not?
answer: It had a hole in the floor. Where are we going? Where are you taking me?

question: What?
answer: Where are you taking me?

question: Ah ... Er ... It looks as if you're taking me.
answer: It does doesn't it?

question: Where are you taking me?
answer: Don't act guilty. Act like me. I'm just getting on with my job. Or, are you just getting on with yours?

question: What's going on here?
answer: What does it look like ... I'm collecting empties.

question: OK. What's in the parcel?
answer: What parcel?

question: It's heavy.
answer: A heavy Christmas present. Open it if you don't trust me.

question: I'd rather trust you.
answer: What are you doing in Information Retrieval?

question: Looking for you.
answer: No, really.

question: Really.
answer: I mean, it doesn't suit you.

question: Suit me?
answer: Don't you know the sort of thing that Information Retrieval does?

question: What do you mean? Would you rather have terrorists?
answer: We've got both.

question: Things would be worse without Information Retrieval.
answer: They couldn't be worse for the Buttles. Why don't you say, no system is perfect.

question: Well, no system is.
answer: Say, all wars have innocent victims.

question: Well, all wars do -
answer: Who is this war against, Sam?

question: Well, terrorists of course.
answer: How many terrorists have you met? Actual terrorists?

question: Actual. terrorists? Well ... it's only my first day.
answer: Look at that - right on time.

question: What? I thought you were free to come and go as you please.
answer: Well, almost ... unfortunately I do have to punch in by 5.00 every day.

question: Every day? Turn around!
answer: What?

question: They'll be there waiting.
answer: Who will?

question: Security.
answer: You're joking.

question: No. Please. They're going to arrest you.
answer: I thought you arrested me.

question: Yes ... but, this is real. Now, stop!
answer: Cut it out, Sam.

question: Will you please turn back.
answer: Get away!

question: Turn!
answer: Stop it ... damn you! You're mad! You're out of your mind!

question: I was right! Step on it!
answer: Let go! We've got to stop!

question: Now you're the one that's out of your mind.
answer: Sam ... we can't outrace them. You'll kill us! Don't touch those! Come on, let's go! Let's get out of here!

question: Oh God! What have we done?
answer: We? Don't blame me!

question: It wasn't supposed to happen like this.
answer: Shit! The house is on fire!

question: "And your children all gone."
answer: What?

question: "Lady bird, lady bird, fly away home, your house is on fire and your children all gone" ... Do you think anyone's hurt?
answer: Yes. Come out, I know you're in there

question: This is a hell of a time to buy a nightie.
answer: Are you still following me?

question: Please, Jill ... I love you.
answer: Go away.

question: There are plenty of other safe places. Why don't we go back to my flat?
answer: Leave me alone!

question: You've got to trust me. It sounds silly but I know we were meant to meet.
answer: You mean you were meant to hijack my truck, make me crash it, and have every security man in town looking for me?

question: I vas just trying to help. I decided to trust you. Maybe I was wrong. Whose side are you on really? Who are your friends? Who was the man who gave you the parcel? What's in it? It's the only thing you saved from the lorry .... It must he something very special.
answer: I saved you from the lorry and you're not very special.

question: ........... It's a bomb isn't it?
answer: Oh ... Jesus!

question: I'm going to open it!
answer: No you're not!

question: It's me and Shirley!
answer: Ah ... hello, Mrs Terrain. SAM lets go of the parcel and pushes JILL away. She moves off. I think that'll hold it. Hello Shirley. Just helping someone tie up a Christmas present. How are you?

question: My complication had a complication, but Dr Chapman says I'll soon be up and bouncing about like a young gazelle. Are you buying a Christmas present for your mother?
answer: Er, yes ...

question: Shirley and I come here regularly. I love romantic lingerie. Picture me in these.
answer: Are you alright?

question: Are you alright?
answer: Yes.

question: You don't deserve to be! You should be dead, or maimed like them .... How could you ...? What a bloody stupid thing ... I should. have made you open it in the lorry
answer: There's your bomb! Our annual bribes for official ass-holes like you! Come on, make yourself useful, there are people hurt! Hey stop ... she's hurt!

question: DON'T TOUCH HER!!
answer: SAM .... don't!!

question: Where is she? Is she here?
answer: These helmets don't half make your scalp itch. I'm lucky, I've got thick eyebrows. That keeps it up and channels it out to my ears. Someone from Information Retrieval they're always hanging about in lingerie.

question: Jill! Jill! Are you there?!
answer: Excuse me, sir - that's government property.

question: Is here a girl here? Tall, fair hair, blue eyes?
answer: Dunno sir. They check all that at the depot.

question: I've got to find her! Jill! Jill!
answer: You can always fill in an application form, if you're a relative, sir. Please stop, sir.

question: Jill! Jill!
answer: Sorry about that sir. Regulations. We'll have you safely back in your office in no time.

question: Shit! Come off it, Jack! Of course you can check to see if she's been arrested.
answer: I'm sorry, Sam, I'm afraid this whole case has become much more complicated since last we talked.

question: She's innocent, Jack --- she's done nothing wrong.
answer: Tell that to the wives of the Security men she blew up this afternoon. Listen, we've also had a report just in from Central Services that Tuttle has wrecked an entire flat and sabotaged adjacent Central Services systems - as a matter of fact, in your block. I'd keep my eyes open if I were you, Sam. Bye.

question: You don't really think Tuttle and the girl are in league?
answer: I do. Goodbye.

question: It could all be coincidental.
answer: There are no coincidences, Sam. Everything's connected, all along the line. Cause and effect. That's the beauty of it. Our job is to trace the connections and reveal them. This whole Buttle/Tuttle confusion was obviously planned from the inside. Bye bye.

question: Jack, she's innocent!
answer: Sam - we've always been close, haven't we?

question: Yes we have, Jack!
answer: Well, could you stay away from me until this thing blows over.

question: You're late.
answer: Jill! What are you do ... I mean ... how did you ... Are you alright?

question: Yes.
answer: What happened to you after ...

question: Your face ... are you hurt?
answer: No. No. I'm fine. I was worried sick about you ... I thought ...

question: They're gone.
answer: Are you sure?

question: Yes.
answer: C'mon, we've got to get you off the streets. For God's sake, what's happened?

question: ... Everything.
answer: This is what you get when you have cowboys round yer ducts.

question: ... yer ducts.
answer: I think you've got your T41 crystal inductor wired up to a reverse bobbin- threaded-solenoid-control. It's either that or a new washer.

question: ... new washer.
answer: Sign the form so we can get to it.

question: My mother said it would be all right.
answer: She didn't say anything about it to me.

question: Well, she's my mother, not yours.
answer: I won't be held responsible.

question: How long will she he away?
answer: There are some who go to Dr. Jaffe's clinic who never come back at all. You're not a professional, are you?

question: No, amateur.
answer: Thank you, Matthews. Make yourself at home. Don't answer the phone or open he door to anyone. I won't be long.

question: Where are you going?
answer: I'm going to pull some strings. It's our only hope.

question: Don't do anything silly.
answer: Thanks for the vote of confidence.

question: Take care.
answer: Excuse me, Dawson, can you put me through to Mr Helpmann's office?

question: Excuse me, Dawson, can you put me through to Mr Helpmann's office?
answer: I'm afraid I can't, sir. You have to go through the proper channels.

question: And you can't tell me what the proper channels are, because that's classified information?
answer: I'm glad to see the Ministry's continuing its tradition of recruiting the brightest and best, sir.

question: Thank you, Dawson. Mr Helpmann? Are you there? Hello? Jill?
answer: What do you think? ... is it me?

question: You don't exist any more. I've killed you. Jill Layton is dead.
answer: Care for a bit of necrophilia? Merry Xmas.

question: Sam, what are we going to do with you? Can you hear me, Sam?
answer: Where's Jill? What have you done to her? Where is she?!

question: Gillian Layton?
answer: Yes, you've got to get me out of here. I've got to find her.

question: I understand, Sam, I know exactly how you feel. So I brought you a bottle of barley water.
answer: Help me!

question: I assure you, Sam, I'm doing everything within my power. But the rules of the game are laid down, and we all have to play by them - even me.
answer: This is all a mistake! Don't you understand?!

question: Yes, well, from the Department's point of view you're certainly a bit of an own goal, but ...
answer: I'm not a terrorist! You must know that! I'm not guilty! Get me out of here!

question: Sam, if you've been going out there and playing a straight bat, all the way down the line, you've got absolutely nothing to worry about.
answer: Please, I've got to find Jill.

question: Sam, I think I ought to tell you ... I'm afraid she's upped stumps and retired to the pavilion.
answer: Dead?

question: Yes, it's all a bit confusing but, it seems she was killed resisting arrest.
answer: No, no ... I did that...

question: Jack? Jack?... Jack?
answer: Shut up!

question: Jack, I'm innocent! Help me.
answer: Bastard!!!

question: This is all a mistake. Jack, please take that mask off.
answer: You stupid bastard!

question: What?
answer: How could you do this to me?

question: Help me, Jack! I'm frightened!
answer: How do you think I feel? You shit!

question: Jack ...
answer: Shut up! This is a professional relationship!
